meaningMnemonic:
A <kanji>mulberry</kanji> <kanji>field</kanji> is a <vocabulary>mulberry field</vocabulary>.

Based on an old belief that lightening does not strike mulberry fields, 桑原 (often recited twice, as in "桑原桑原") can also be used as a charm to ward off undesirable events, though it's pretty old-fashioned.

Apart from that use, 桑原 now mainly refers to the family name <vocabulary>Kuwabara</vocabulary>, like one of the main protagonists of the anime and manga series 幽遊白書.
readingMnemonic:
These are both the kun'yomi readings, but you haven't learned this for 原 yet. It's actually the rendaku'd version, so let's just use a mnemonic to remember it instead:

You know you're in a <vocabulary>mulberry field</vocabulary> when you see a bunch of capy<reading>bara</reading>s (ばら) rolling around in there with you. Capybaras love mulberries! Picture a whole family of capybaras munching on mulberries. Mm Mmm!
